content.description:
Short sport route on easy terrain. Navigate your way up to the large ledge where you find access to the only bolt on the route. A couple more jug pulls finds you on top of another ledge with easy access to the two bolt anchor.

Good for a warm up, but may be a little run out for teaching a new leader.
content.location: The first climb on the section of wall left of Roy Davies. There's several other low difficulty sport routes to the left of this one.

content.description: Follow 2 bolts to the middle anchor on the ledge.
content.protection: 2 bolts + bolted anchor.  Plenty of places to plug your own additional pro as well.

content.description: Climb through one bolt to the left-most of the 3 anchors on the ledge.
content.protection: 1 bolt + bolted anchor.  A few medium cams and maybe a small nut or two.  This climb can be well protected even without using the bolt.

content.location: Right of the hemlock, starts on 2 bolts

content.description: Start at the hueco behind the tree left of Roy Davies. Climb the ledgey arete until you reach the top of the flake. Move up and right onto the rock face to finish on super easy jugs with a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Good. Standard rack up to a two bolt anchor
content.location: Behind the large tree near the right side of Tan Wall.

content.description: Something else that is dubious is the history of this climb. There was a fixed tat anchor at a wet spot halfway up. I took it to the top and added anchors. Another friend told me that it's at least been toproped to the top. Either way, it's worthy enough for inclusion
content.protection: Bring a big boy for the top
content.location: Left of the climb formerly known as Campground Sluts

content.description: Good holds to slightly overhanging at the bolt
content.protection: Standard rack, one bolt, 2 bolt anchor

content.description: Fun route with some bomber moves. 1.5” mono halfway up.
content.location: To the right of DC memorial face

content.description: Climbs better than it looks. Up past a bolt on the face, then through the short dihedral. Jugs over the roof to another bolt, then bolted anchors above
content.protection: Standard rack of cams, 2 bolts, 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Right facing flake with a bolt in the middle, under a short dihedral and roof

content.description: More bulbous rock with horizontal slots for placements

Right smack in the middle of the Tan Wall. Look for a glue-in eye bolt about 15' off the ground just above a small overhang to start. Continue straight up the juggy face, placing as much medium-sized pro as you want. Great chicken head to sling near the top.

Top out on a ledge to two glue-ins with c-links.

Great beginner trad lead or warmup.
content.protection:
Treat this like a trad climb. Only two bolts and anchors.

Nuts, sling(s), tricams.
content.location: Middle of Tan Wall at Meadow River area near New River Gorge.

content.description: Starting on the first two bolts as the Campground Vanlifer Trustafarians climb straight up the white face. Negotiate a crimpy and balancy middle section on your way to a fun finish.
content.location: White face under a small roof with two bolt lines sharing the start and the finish.

content.description: The rock is better than it looks, crux is low. The first to second bolt is committing, you won't deck, make sure you have an attentive belay. Don't rush the top, it tends to stay cryptic due to lichen coverage.
content.location: The route starts in a wide dihedral with the first moves starting beneath a roof ramp.

content.description: Climb jugs up the face to a short right angling crack, then straight up to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 glue-in bolts to a 2 glue-in bolt anchor with rings
content.location: About 100 feet left of the Roy Davies wall. Bolted line with short left angling crack towards the top.

content.description: Start on the same two bolts as D.C. Memorial Face. After clipping the second bolt go left on a balancy ledge. A couple of mantles and two home-made bolts will bring you to the anchor shared with D.C. Memorial Face.
content.location: White face under a small roof with two bolt lines sharing the start and the finish.

content.description: Follow the mini-dihedral feature through jugs to a gently overhanging finish.
Follow left-facing flakes to a hueco and anchors.

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: Unknown.  May have been climbed before but there was no chalk and the bottom is thick with rhodos.  Maybe me, not sure.

content.description: Start under a roof at a breadloaf jug.  For shorter climbers, this will definitely be a jump off the ground.  Match that hold and pull through a roof, then figure out the crux pulling the second bulge.  After this, the climbing is still fun, but much, much easier to the anchor.  It's not a one move wonder, but the physical climbing is over pretty quickly.  A great short option for newish trad climbers looking for a safe but exciting challenge- or a good warmup for trad climbers that can pull the harder things in the area.
content.protection: A .75 and a 1 get you through the overhangs.  From there the options for pro increase as the difficulty decreases.  I used another .75 and a (probably unnecessary) .3 below the anchor.  New bolted anchor with rings just under the last little roof at the top.
content.location: Look for the first chunk of rock right where the trail forks for Upper Meadow and Lower Meadow.  You'll see a small cave and the start of the route is masked by rhododendrons on the ground.  You can't miss the start hold though once you see it.
